8vb.title: Locale
8vb.text:
A **locale** is a structure which captures the relations between possible observations. 

They are very similar to topological spaces - the open sets of any topology form a locale. However,  they have better properties than topologies in many contexts, for example - they can be used when constructive math is required.
See Peter Johnstone's [The point of pointless topology](http://pointlesstopology.com/the-point-of-pointless-topology.pdf) for an overview of these benefits.

#Why locales?
Locales model observations, and thus turn up in a very wide variety of contexts. In particular, they model *affirmable* observations - observations which, if true, can be affirmed by a witness. For example, "Some crows are black" is an affirmable observation, since we could affirm it by the existence of a black crow. On the other hand, "All crows are black" is *not* an affirmable observation. The locale is a system of affirmable observations which we call **opens**. %%note: The example "All crows are black" *is* however a *refutable* observation, since the existence of a white crow would refute it. Refutable observations are called **closeds**, and are also a part of the locale structure. We incorporate them by identifying them with their negations, which are affirmative!%%

Observations can have more or less information. This gives them a [3rb poset] structure. We say that the more specific open *refines* the more generic open. To say $A$ refines $B$, we write $A\le B$. A witness affirming $A$ will also affirm $B$.  

Observations can be combined to make a higher information observation. We call this combination the **meet** of our observations, and write it as $\bigwedge A_i$ or $A \wedge B$. Think of this as $A$ *and* $B$. If incompatible observations are combined, we get the bottom element of the poset: $\bot$ - representing false. We can only combine a finite number of observations - this is to keep things computable. 

Observations can cover an arbitrary set of observations as specific possibilities. We call this the **join** of our opens, and write it as $\bigvee A_i$ or $A \vee B$. Think of this as $A$ *or* $B$. Together with finite meets, this gives the locale a [46c lattice] structure. The top element of the poset $\top$ represents true, and is the most generic observation.

Joins and meets must be compatible with each other. In particular, they must satisfy the distributive law: $A\wedge \bigvee A_i = \bigvee (A \wedge A_i)$. I'm still confused about why exactly this is a natural condition to impose.


%%note: Note that there are some ontological commitments that locales make: that the order of observations doesn't matter,  and that observations don't affect the world. Quantales generalize locales to remove these commitments!%%



## Category perspective
A poset can be considered as a category, the elements are the objects, and the order relation defines the morphisms: $A \le B$ implies there's a morphism $A \rightarrow B$. The meet is then the product, and the join is the coproduct! Initial object of course is $\bot$, and final object is $\top$. Morphisms can also be interpreted as logical implication! 

Locales themselves can be the object of a category. In fact, they are the objects of multiple important categories!

### Morphisms

What is a morphism of locales? It's not a functor! It's easiest to describe them in the opposite category. Here, they are functions between locales which preserve finite meets and arbitrary joins. A locale morphism is called a **continuous map**. Computable functions must be continuous.

# Examples

## The locale of real numbers

Opens are generated by rational intervals. 

## More examples

 - Open sets of any topology
 - Logical propositions 
 - Ideals of a commutative ring



#Important concepts
- Sublocale
- Point
- Separation
 - Regularity is the most natural separation axiom, not Hausdorff (which *can* be defined for locales)
- Compactness
- Fundamental groupoid
 - Much intuitively clearer to define and use!

#How do we use them?
##Conceptual clarity

I've found that replacing topological spaces with locales typically brings about conceptual clarity when working on something. This effect seems to be stronger the less obvious it is to make the replacement. Topological spaces bring lots of baggage with them, with all the sets and the axiom of choice. Once these have been dropped, it becomes easier to see what's actually going on, to move! Think of this as analogous to replacing Roman numerals with Arabic numerals - it's not really that you can do anything that you couldn't do before, it just becomes significantly easier to do things! 

##Constructive analysis
The real line always felt like such a complicated thing to drag into the laws of physics, there must be something better! In order to do physics with that something, we'd better be able to do analysis. Luckily, locales are very promising in this regard!

- Heine-Borel
- Constructive Tychonoff!




#References

 1. Stone Spaces by Peter Johnstone
 2. Topology via Logic by Stephen Vickers
 3. [Locale - nLab](https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/locale)
